name: TIBCO DataSynapse GridServer
description: GridServer Manager is a highly scalable software infrastructure that allows application services to operate in a virtualized fashion, unattached to specific hardware resources.

name: IBM Spectrum Symphony
description: IBM Spectrum Symphony software delivers powerful enterprise-class management for running compute-intensive and data-intensive distributed applications on a scalable, shared grid.

name: IBM Spectrum LSF
description: IBM Spectrum LSF Suites is a workload management platform and job scheduler for distributed high performance computing (HPC). A Terraform-based automation to provision and configure resources for an IBM Spectrum LSF based cluster on IBM Cloud® is available.

name: Yellowdog
description: YellowDog’s Dynamic Workload Manager specialises in accelerating large-scale, complex, computationally intensive workloads, with rapid scaling and advanced preemption handling to maximise cloud cost/performance, whilst also interworking seamlessly with on-premise resources.

name: Slurm
description: Slurm’s ability to allocate resources based on time duration makes it the ideal application for HPC job scheduling. In fact, Slurm is used by approximately 65% of supercomputers run by the TOP500.

name: AWS Parallel Computing Service (Slurm)
description: AWS Parallel Computing Service (AWS PCS) is a managed service that makes it easier for you to run and scale your high performance computing (HPC) workloads and build scientific and engineering models on AWS using Slurm.

details.freeSoftware: AWS PCS is a commercial offering from Amazon Web Services but is based on Slurm.
details.openSourceSoftware: AWS PCS is a commercial offering from Amazon Web Services.
details.commercialSupport: Commercial support is available for AWS PCS and is dependent on your level of AWS Enterprise support: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/plans/
details.typicalTaskDuration: AWS PCS is not designed for very short, high-throughput use-cases.
details.taskSubmissionRate: AWS PCS is not designed for very short, high-throughput use-cases.
details.supportForContainers: AWS PCS does not currently have native container support.
details.dataAwareScheduling: AWS PCS does not allow compute tasks to be directed towards instances with data in place.
details.onPremisesScheduler: AWS PCS can only be run in AWS.
details.managedCloudResources: AWS PCS can create/remove compute resources as needed
details.managedCloudSolution: Yes, AWS PCS is a managed solution.
details.cloudAWSIntegration: AWS PCS is an AWS servivce
details.IntegrationK8: AWS PCS currently leverages AWS EC2 compute planes and does not have native Kubernetes integration.
details.advancedCapacityProvisioning: AWS PCS allows you to set your compute requirements.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: PCS is not supported on Azure
details.cloudGCPIntegration: PCS is not support on GCP

name: AWS Batch
description: AWS Batch is a fully managed batch computing service that plans, schedules, and runs your containerized batch ML, simulation, and analytics workloads across the full range of AWS compute offerings, such as Amazon ECS, Amazon EKS, AWS Fargate, and Spot or On-Demand Instances.

details.freeSoftware: There is no additional charge for AWS Batch. You pay for AWS resources (e.g. EC2 instances, AWS Lambda functions or AWS Fargate) you create to store and run your application.
details.openSourceSoftware: AWS Batch is a commercial offering from Amazon Web Services.
details.commercialSupport: Commercial support is available for AWS Batch and is dependent on your level of AWS Enterprise support: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/plans/
details.typicalTaskDuration: AWS Batch is not designed for very short, high-throughput use-cases.
details.taskSubmissionRate: AWS Batch is not designed for very short, high-throughput use-cases.
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Windows containers are supported but only using Amazon ECS Fargate.
details.supportForContainers: AWS Batch supports container/multi-container workloads via ECS, Fargate, and EKS: https://aws.amazon.com/batch/faqs/#topic-0
details.arm64CPUSupport: AWS Batch supports both X86_64 and ARM64 vCPU architecture. For Windows container workloads, you must use X86_64. Fargate Spot is not supported for ARM64 and Windows-based containers on Fargate. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/batch/latest/userguide/create-compute-environment.html
details.gpuSupport: AWS Batch supports GPU scheduling, but not when using Fargate as your compute environment. You can utilize instances from the p2, p3, p4, p5, g3, g3s, g4, or g5 families: https://aws.amazon.com/batch/faqs/#topic-5
details.advancedResourceScheduling: AWS Batch allows different pools of resources to be configured and shared with 'fair share' scheduling.
details.dataAwareScheduling: AWS Batch does not allow compute tasks to be directed towards instances with data in place.
details.onPremisesScheduler: AWS Batch can only be run in AWS.
details.managedCloudResources: AWS Batch can create/remove compute resources as needed
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: AWS Batch supports utilizing Spot Instances: https://aws.amazon.com/batch/faqs/#topic-3
details.managedCloudSolution: Yes, AWS Batch is a managed solution.
details.cloudAWSIntegration: AWS Batch is an AWS servivce
details.IntegrationK8: AWS Batch currently leverages AWS EKS and ECS compute planes.
details.advancedCapacityProvisioning: AWS Batch allows you to set your compute requirements.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: No Azure implementation has been built.
details.cloudGCPIntegration: No GCP implementation has been built.

name: Microsoft HPC Pack
description: Microsoft HPC Pack brings the power of high-performance computing (HPC) to the commercial mainstream. The centralized management and deployment interface helps to simplify deployment for both large and small compute clusters and provide a simple and effective management experience in order to increase cluster administrator productivity.

name: HTC-Grid
description: The high throughput compute grid project (HTC-Grid) is a container based cloud native HPC/Grid environment. The project provides a reference architecture that can be used to build and adapt a modern High throughput compute solution using underlying AWS services, allowing users to submit high volumes of short and long running tasks and scaling environments dynamically.

details.freeSoftware: HTC-Grid is open source software, currently owned by the FINOS foundation and available under the Apache License version 2.0 licence.
details.openSourceSoftware: HTC-Grid is open source software, currently owned by the FINOS foundation and available under the Apache License version 2.0 licence.
details.commercialSupport: There is currently no commercial support for HTC-Grid
details.typicalTaskDuration: HTC-Grid is designed to support short tasks of under 1 seconds and throughputs of thousands of tasks per second. More detail can be found here: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/hpc/operational-characteristics-of-htc-grid/
details.taskSubmissionRate: HTC-Grid has been demonstrated supporting around 30,000 tasks per second in batches of 100.
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Windows compute nodes have not currently been tested but should be possible.
details.supportForContainers: The current version of HTC-Grid requires the workers to be packaged as containers
details.arm64CPUSupport: Support for ARM64 is possible but is currently untested.
details.gpuSupport: Support for GPUs is possible but is currently untested.
details.advancedResourceScheduling: HTC-Grid does not offer advanced scheduling options
details.dataAwareScheduling: HTC-Grid does not currently support data-aware scheduling
details.onPremisesScheduler: The HTC-Grid control plane is currently dependent on AWS services including Amazon SQS, DynamoDB and Lambda.
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: This is supported through Amazon EKS.
details.managedCloudSolution: No. This is a self-managed open-source solution.
details.IntegrationK8: HTC-Grid currently leverages EKS compute planes.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: No Azure implementation has been built.
details.cloudGCPIntegration: No GCP implementation has been built.

details.typicalTaskDuration: ArmoniK can be configured to provide a median roundtrip latency of 38ms. Hence, ArmoniK can easily schedule tasks shorter than 1 second. On the other hands, production deployment often face some tasks that lasts for few hours.
details.taskSubmissionRate: Task can be submitted in batches of 100, allowing to submit thousands of tasks per seconds within a single session. Some details can be found on our (incomplete) benchmark page: https://armonik.readthedocs.io/en/latest/content/benchmarking/benchmarking-armonik-v2.12.3.html
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Integration for Windows worker has been developed. It is considered as beta as it hasn't been through extensive testing yet. https://github.com/aneoconsulting/ArmoniK.Core
details.supportForContainers: As of today, ArmoniK requires the workers to be packaged as containers
details.arm64CPUSupport: Support for ARM64 is in preview. We use it in our every day tests and for demo with our portable Raspberry cluster: https://github.com/aneoconsulting/ArmoniK.Core
details.gpuSupport: ArmoniK supports GPU. However, it is the responsibility of the users to manage the GPU code and the data transfer between CPU and GPU. An example of how GPU nodes can be configured can be found here https://github.com/aneoconsulting/ArmoniK/blob/fd6a1ddefd90d14fc34e7f144d58c1b3d61aab53/infrastructure/quick-deploy/aws/parameters.tfvars#L72
details.advancedResourceScheduling: ArmoniK partitions can be used to provide autoscaling rules for each users. This is done by exposing custom metric that can take into consideration external elements such as cluster occupation, time: https://armonik.readthedocs.io/en/latest/content/armonik/glossary.html#partition
details.dataAwareScheduling: ArmoniK jobs are described as graphs of data and tasks. In a Session, data can be shared amongst any tasks. ArmoniK manages data transfer to a worker while the previous task is running (replicating communication-computation overlapping from advanced MPI programming). We recommend that a session should only run on a single distributed ArmoniK environment. An ArmoniK provides a load balancer to distribute session across different ArmoniK environment.
details.onPremisesScheduler: ArmoniK can be deployed on any Kubernetes infrastructure. See installation guide.
details.managedCloudResources: As of today, ArmoniK relies on managed Kubernetes services to manage cloud resources. Future development will rely on other managed services such as AWS Autoscaling Groups or GCP's Managed Instance Groups to provide the same feature without Kubernetes. ArmoniK leverages Kubernetes' Pod Deletion Cost to reduce the likelihood of worker eviction during scaledown phases.
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: Done through Kubernetes machine pool definitions.
details.managedCloudSolution: No. Although Market-place deployments are under development.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: No specific Azure Integration has been developed yet. However, one can use ArmoniK on Azure using the vanilla Kubernetes deployment.

name: HTCondor
description: HTCondor is a workload management system for distributing work across a wide variety of compute resources, from single machines to massive clusters.

name: Flux Framework
description: Flux is a hierarchical, event-driven workload manager that uses resource brokers and dynamic job graphs to provide scalable, flexible, and efficient orchestration of complex scientific workflows on extreme-scale computing systems.

details.openSourceSoftware: Flux Framework projects are available under open source LICENSE on GitHub: https://github.com/flux-framework
details.commercialSupport: The Flux Framework developers team can respond to questions or issues on GitHub boards or via mailing list.
details.typicalTaskDuration: Flux Framework can handle tasks that range from seconds to days or weeks, depending on the cluster configuration that defines a maximum running time. Most HPC jobs are in the order of minutes to hours.
details.taskSubmissionRate: Flux Framework can achieve ~500 jobs/second on simple setups. Flux batch or bringing in hierarchical submission extends that to over 1K jobs/second.
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Flux Framework is not supported on Windows.
details.supportForContainers: Flux works well with container technologies (e.g., Singularity/Apptainer, CharlieCloud, and Podman) for managing application environments and dependencies. Most HPC environments do not allow for rootful container runtimes.
details.arm64CPUSupport: Flux tests for ARM64 and several cloud environments that use entirely ARM64 have been provisioned (e.g., Graviton2 and Graviton3 on AWS).
details.gpuSupport: Flux enabled with the Fluxion 'flux-sched' resource and queue manager provides support for scheduling to GPUs. Both NVIDIA and AMD have been extensively used.
details.advancedResourceScheduling: Flux provides advanced resource scheduling and support for multi-tenancy, with support for job priority, custom scheduler policies, and reservations.
details.dataAwareScheduling: Flux provide an ability to move data between brokers that do not share a filesystem with 'flux archive'
details.onPremisesScheduler: Flux Framework can be deployed on-premises (bare metal), on cloud virtual machines, or Kubernetes infrastructure.
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: The Flux Operator (Kubernetes) easily supports spot instances by way of scaling up and down of brokers.
details.managedCloudSolution: The Flux team provides Terraform deployments across clouds for deployment on virtual machines, and the Flux Operator for Kubernetes (e.g., AKS, EKS, GKE).
details.cloudAWSIntegration: Flux can be deployed to AWS via the Flux Operator (EKS) or Bare Metal VMs (EC2 with Terraform)
details.IntegrationK8: The Flux Operator can deploy a Flux cluster on any Kubernetes cluster.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: Flux can be deployed to Azure via the Flux Operator (AKS) or Bare Metal VMs (Terraform)
details.cloudGCPIntegration: Flux can be deployed to Google Cloud via the Flux Operator (GKE) or Bare Metal VMs (Compute Engine with Terraform)

name: Open Cluster Scheduler
description: Open Cluster Scheduler is a drop-in replacement for Sun Grid Engine (SGE), Son of Grid Engine (SoGE) and and similar HPC schedulers with modern features, stable operation, and ultra-fast performance. It is open source under the SISSL v2 and Apache 2.0 licenses, providing SGE-compatible interfaces for seamless migration.

details.freeSoftware: Open Cluster Scheduler is free and open source software, available under the SISSL v2 and Apache License 2.0.
details.openSourceSoftware: Open Cluster Scheduler is fully open source, continuing the development of Univa Open Core Grid Engine and Sun Grid Engine.
details.commercialSupport: No commercial support is provided for Open Cluster Scheduler. For commercial support, consider Gridware Cluster Scheduler.
details.typicalTaskDuration: Open Cluster Scheduler supports a wide range of task durations from short high-throughput tasks to long-running HPC jobs.
details.taskSubmissionRate: Open Cluster Scheduler can handle millions of jobs with high throughput scheduling capabilities inherited from SGE/UGE and further improved by the team.
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Windows compute nodes are not currently supported.
details.supportForContainers: Open Cluster Scheduler has container support including Apptainer/Singularity, enroot, and other HPC container runtimes.
details.arm64CPUSupport: ARM64 architecture is fully supported including Grace Hopper/Grace Blackwell.
details.gpuSupport: GPU support is available through RSMAP resource type for efficient GPU management.
details.advancedResourceScheduling: Advanced scheduling features including fair-share, resource quotas, and complex job dependencies are supported.
details.dataAwareScheduling: Data-aware scheduling is not a native feature.
details.onPremisesScheduler: Open Cluster Scheduler is designed for on-premises deployment.
details.managedCloudResources: No native cloud resource management. Cloud deployment is possible but not managed.
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: Spot capacity is not directly supported.
details.managedCloudSolution: This is a self-managed open source solution.
details.cloudAWSIntegration: No direct AWS integration. Can be deployed on AWS VMs.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: No direct Azure integration. Can be deployed on Azure VMs.
details.cloudGCPIntegration: No direct GCP integration. Can be deployed on GCP VMs.

name: Gridware Cluster Scheduler
description: Gridware Cluster Scheduler is an enterprise-grade workload manager built on Open Cluster Scheduler, offering enhanced features including advanced GPU support, License Manager integration, cache-aware scheduling, and qtelemetry monitoring (Prometheus / Grafana). It provides SGE-compatible interfaces with commercial support and consulting services.

details.freeSoftware: Gridware Cluster Scheduler is a commercial product with licensing fees. Pre-built binaries are available from HPC-Gridware GmbH.
details.openSourceSoftware: Gridware Cluster Scheduler is partially open source. The core is based on Open Cluster Scheduler (open source), with additional commercial features.
details.commercialSupport: Full commercial support and consulting services are available from HPC-Gridware GmbH. Contact sales@hpc-gridware.com for details.
details.typicalTaskDuration: Gridware Cluster Scheduler supports a wide range of task durations from sub-second high-throughput tasks to long-running HPC and AI workloads.
details.taskSubmissionRate: Gridware Cluster Scheduler can handle millions of jobs with ultra-fast scheduling performance.
details.microsoftWindowsComputeNodes: Windows compute nodes are not currently supported.
details.supportForContainers: Full container support including Apptainer/Singularity, enroot, and other HPC container runtimes for running containerized workloads.
details.arm64CPUSupport: ARM64 architecture is fully supported including Grace Hopper/Grace Blackwell.
details.gpuSupport: Advanced GPU support with RSMAP resource type, optimized for NVIDIA GPUs including DGX systems. Supports HPC and AI workflows with efficient GPU allocation. Per job GPU accounting is available. Monitoring through qtelemetry.
details.advancedResourceScheduling: Advanced scheduling features including License Manager integration, cache-aware scheduling, fair-share, resource quotas, and complex job dependencies.
details.dataAwareScheduling: Cache-aware scheduling enables data locality optimizations for improved performance.
details.onPremisesScheduler: Gridware Cluster Scheduler is primarily designed for on-premises deployment.
details.managedCloudResources: No native cloud resource management. Cloud support is available through 3rd party vendors.
details.supportCloudSpotCapacity: Spot capacity support is available through 3rd party cloud integrations.
details.managedCloudSolution: This is not a managed cloud solution. Deployment and management are handled on-premises or through partners.
details.cloudAWSIntegration: No direct AWS integration. Cloud deployment available through 3rd party vendors.
details.IntegrationK8: Kubernetes integration is possible and demonstrated but not yet an official feature.
details.advancedCapacityProvisioning: No native cloud capacity provisioning. Available through 3rd party integrations.
details.cloudAzureIntegration: No direct Azure integration. Cloud deployment available through 3rd party vendors.
details.cloudGCPIntegration: No direct GCP integration. Cloud deployment available through 3rd party vendors.
